title: Dow Industrials Test Super Breakout Price Level!
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has survived several market scares over the past 5 decades, including the 1987 crash (Black Monday), Tech Bubble, Financial Crisis, and Coronavirus crash. In a very noisy, news-driven world, sometimes it pays to simply zoom out on the charts and stop thinking about trading every headline.

title: U.S. Dollar to Weaken Into 2021, Says JPMorgan AM's Callegari

title: Investors: Is Junk (Bonds) Worth More Than Gold?
text: In Santa Fem New Mexico we awoke with freezing temperatures and fresh snow.  This week the state lifted the current lockdown with restaurants now being able to serve at 25% occupancy outdoors.

title: Jim Cramer reveals stock plays for the reopening trade
text: "Once we get closer to herd immunity, everything that got put on hold, everything, during the pandemic can make a comeback," the "Mad Money" host said.

text: "Once we get closer to herd immunity, everything that got put on hold, everything, during the pandemic can make a comeback," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Dollar wallows near 2 1/2-year low on vaccine, stimulus optimism
text: The dollar licked wounds near a 2 1/2-year low against a basket of major currencies on Thursday as investors wagered that more economic stimulus from Washington and the expected start of COVID-19 vaccinations would support riskier assets.

title: 'We're positive that it will be a good end to 2020,' Ally Invest's top investment strategist says
text: Ally Invest's Lindsey Bell sees a traditional year-end rally unfolding despite rising coronavirus cases and stimulus uncertainty.

title: White House says Trump to sign bill that could delist Chinese companies from U.S. exchanges
text: The White House announces President Trump may sign a bill that could delist Chinese companies from U.S. stock exchanges. Barbara Ann Bernard, Wincrest Capital CEO, discusses with CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Karen Finerman and Dan Nathan.

title: Rally is entering a temporary 'chill zone' warns Canaccord's Tony Dwyer
text: Canaccord Genuity's Tony Dwyer says investors should expect a December chill for the market. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Karen Finerman and Dan Nathan.

title: Stocks to Be Thankful For
text: In this Thanksgiving special, Motley Fool analysts share some stocks they are thankful for this year and more.

title: Stock futures rise slightly as Wall Street awaits news on stimulus, vaccines
text: U.S. stock futures held steady on Wednesday evening as investors awaited news on stimulus negotiations and the vaccine approval process.

title: Small-Caps Are Consolidating; Large-Caps Are Poised To Move Higher (Technically Speaking For 12/2)
text: The UK was the first country to approve the Pfizer vaccine.

title: S&P 500 Sees Record High as Consumer Discretionary Stocks Bust Out
text: U.S. equity markets bounced out of early losses to notch slight gains for the DJIA and the S&P 500, which topped a new closing high.

title: Bill forcing Chinese firms to meet U.S. accounting standards passes Congress
text: The U.S. House of Representatives passed legislation on Wednesday that could prevent Chinese companies from listing their shares on U.S. exchanges unless they adhere to U.S. auditing standards.

text: The rising tide that lifted all boats in the industry earlier this year isn't providing the same boost anymore.

title: The Dow Rose 60 Points Because a Stimulus Bill Trumps a Poor Jobs Report
text: Stocks eked out a gain Wednesday, with the S&P 500 setting a record, even though the jobs report was a disappointment. A new fiscal stimulus package seems to be back on the table.

title: The Fed: Fed's Kaplan says he's worried the U.S. economy might stall out
text: If the economy can weather this short-term contraction, it should rebound as 2021 progresses, Dallas Fed president says.

title: Stock market recap for Wednesday, December 2: S&P closes at all-time high
text: The S&P 500 turned slightly positive intraday on Wednesday after opening lower, as traders paused after Tuesday's rally. Energy shares led gains as crude oil rebounded from a day earlier.

title: Stock Market Today: Stocks Fight to Extend Rally Despite Disappointing Payrolls
text: The stock market spent most of Wednesday trying to dig itself out of a hole as investors continued to chew on renewed stimulus discussions in Washington. Earlier in the day, payroll services firm ADP reported that the U.S. added just 307,000 private-sector jobs in November – a firm decline from October's 404,000 jobs created and well below most economists' estimates.

title: US stocks erase losses, finish higher amid renewed stimulus optimism
text: After an initial morning decline, US stocks finished mostly higher on Wednesday as investors latched onto hope that another round of fiscal stimulus to hasten the economic recovery is just around the corner. Democratic leaders embraced a bipartisan stimulus deal that would include up to $908 billion in funding for various initiatives, including expanded unemployment benefits and an extension of the paycheck protection program.

title: 'There's been two economies in this pandemic,' Veritas Financial's Greg Branch explains
text: Greg Branch, Managing Partner of Veritas Financial, joined Yahoo Finance Live to discuss his market outlook and how the latest developments regarding stimulus talks are impacting the market. title: US Indexes Close Mostly Higher Wednesday
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 29,883.79 on Wednesday with a gain of 59.87 points or 0.20%. The S&P 500 closed at 3,669.01 for a gain of 6.56 points or 0.18%.

title: Kaplan says he's not in favor of Fed increasing bond purchases
text: Kaplan said he wouldn't be in favor of changing the bond-purchasing program even though he sees rocky times ahead for the economy.

title: 'Shark Tank' investor Kevin O'Leary says bitcoin is too volatile for his portfolio — but says he would own a crypto ETF
text: Shark Tank investor Kevin O'Leary told The Pomp Podcast on Tuesday that bitcoin is too volatile and illiquid for his portfolio, but he would consider owning a basket of cryptocurrencies in an ETF.   O'Leary has created multiple ETFs as the chairman of O'Shares, and he said that a crypto ETF could be the most liquid way to buy and sell bitcoin. The investor said that right now there are too many fees associated with getting in and out of bitcoin, but he does own a little bit of the coin right now.

title: The next three to six months will be challenging, but long-term growth is strong: Dallas Fed Pres.
text: Dallas Fed president Robert Kaplan says continued spikes in coronavirus cases will make the next three to six months challenging, creating a slowdown in growth. But despite this, Kaplan says the long-term growth is strong as current financial conditions are accommodative.

title: S&P 500 notches 28th record close of 2020 but stock market posts tepid gain on Wednesday
text: U.S. stock benchmarks finished the session slightly higher on Wednesday, with the slight gains enough to notch a fresh all-time high for the S&P 500 index. Gains for the broad-market benchmark were driven by a surge in the energy sector, up 3%, and financials, 1.1% higher, to help the S&P 500 eke out a 0.2% gain to reach 3,669, despite over 1% declines in materials and real estate.

title: The Good News Is...
text: Stocks started the final month of the year in fine fashion.

title: M&A Activity in Early Innings, Morgan Stanley's Rossi Says
text: Dec.02 -- Kristen Rossi, Morgan Stanley's global head of consumer retail investment banking, says the company is "geared up" for high M&A activity. She speaks with Bloomberg's Ed Hammond on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close.

title: Powell, Mnuchin testify on pandemic response
text: Fed Chair Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin testified before the House Financial Services Committee. Yahoo Finance's Brian Cheung shares the details.

title: Why Mario Gabelli remains optimistic about 2021
text: Mario Gabelli, Gamco Investors chairman and CEO, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss his outlook for 2021, why he remains optimistic and where he sees opportunity in the market.

title: Economic Report: Several regions of U.S. are experiencing little or no economic growth: Fed Beige Book survey
text: Several areas of the country experienced an economic slowdown in November as COVID-19 cases surged, according to the Fed's latest Beige Book survey released Wednesday.

title: U.S. Bond Market Needs Growth Shock to Rally: JPM's Normand
text: Dec.02 -- John Normand, head of cross-asset fundamental strategy at JPMorgan, explains why it is “incredibly difficult” to get back to higher yields in the U.S. and offers his view of economic recovery in 2021. He speaks on “Bloomberg Surveillance.

title: Deutsche Bank's Hooper Sees Negative Q1 GDP Without Stimulus
text: Dec.02 -- Peter Hooper, global head of economic research at Deutsche Bank Securities, discusses his U.S. economic outlook and the need for further unemployment stimulus and a continuation of the PPP program. He speaks on “Bloomberg Surveillance.

title: Markets Say Second-Half 2021 Could Be a Boom: BNY Mellon's Levine
text: Dec.02 -- Alicia Levine, chief strategist at BNY Mellon Investment Management, discusses what markets are pricing in with the S&P 500 near record highs and Treasury yields rising for a third day. She speaks with Bloomberg's David Westin on “Balance of Power.

title: Fed: Little to no growth in four of 12 regions as stress mounts
text: Federal Reserve officials saw "little or no growth" in four of their 12 U.S. districts and only modest growth elsewhere in recent weeks amid a rapidly spreading health crisis and the impact of a recession that has devastated some businesses and families even as many others thrive.

title: Many Of The 22 Million Lost Jobs ‘May Never Return' And A Recovery Is Already ‘Plateauing': Philly Fed President
text: Minority workers are more likely than other groups to hold jobs that could be lost permanently to automation, Federal Reserve researchers found.

title: Modest to moderate increases in input prices: Beige Book

title: Central Banks Contain Future Volatility in Some Markets, Not All
text: By Erik Norland Nearly one year into the pandemic, market participants have grown accustomed to reduced activity across most major economies, governments running large fiscal deficits, and central banks easing monetary policy to overcome weak growth. Amid these economic changes, implied volatility in some markets, notably short-term interest rates, credit markets and currencies, have returned to pre-pandemic levels.

title: Fed not considering pulling back on bond-buying in light of COVID-19 vaccine optimism
text: The U.S. central bank is not thinking about pulling back on its bond-buying program given the optimism about the coronavirus vaccine, said Fed Chairman Jerome Powell on Wednesday.
